bioghist.p: Francis Fisher Kane (1866-1955) and his sister Eliza Middleton Kane Cope (1863-1952) were the children of Robert Patterson Kane (1827-1906) and Elizabeth Francis Fisher (1840-1919). Robert Kane was the brother of the well-known Arctic explorer Elisha K. Kane (1820-1857) and the son of John Kintzing Kane (1795-1858), a prominent Philadelphia lawyer and Judge of the District Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Like his grandfather, Francis F. Kane was a lawyer and served as an Attorney for the District Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania (1913-1920). Eliza's husband Walter Cope (1860-1902) was a principal of the architectural firm Cope and Stewardson and a founding member of the of the T-Square Club.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers related to several Kane family members. Eliza Middleton Kane Cope (Mrs. Walter Cope) materials include: correspondence with family and friends, including her husband and her children Elizabeth, Thomas, and Oliver; a small number of manuscript and typescript form letters related to the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom and the Committee for Total Disarmament; a herbarium; and photographs. The Walter Cope materials include correspondence, mostly personal, and receipts for travel to Europe in the 1880s. Materials related to Francis Fisher Kane include: genealogical records of the Kane, Middleton, Foulke, and Fisher families; personal letters from family and friends, including letters from Elisha K. Kane on prohibition (1918) and other political matters; incoming and outgoing business letters related to his private law practice and associations with which he was involved, including the Philadelphia Bar Association and the Pennsylvania State Negro Council; incoming and outgoing letters from his time as U.S. District Attorney for Eastern Pennsylvania (such as letters of recommendation and announcements of postings); estate documents; printed court transcripts; clippings; composition books; and photographs. Items in the collection documenting John K. Kane include: claims, affidavits, summonses and receipts; printed pamphlets, addresses, and legal opinions including "An Appeal on Behalf of Idiots" and "Passmore Williamson vs. John K. Kane"; typescript memoir by John K. Kane, entitled "Myself from 1795 to 1849" by Myself; and a small number of photos. The collection also contains a scrapbook kept by Mrs. A.K. Audi, including music programs, invitations, and clippings (1915-1922).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: American Philosophical Society: Elisha Kent Kane papers, Francis Fisher Kane papers, John Kintzing Kane papers, Robert Patterson Kane papers, and Thomas Leiper Kane papers; Historical Society of Pennsylvania: John Kintzing Kane papers and Florence Bayard Kane papers.
